quote: Head into it!
We've slipped between two thermal layers... wind velocities are a little more manageable here.
Hold this altitude. Any sign of the Karemma or the Jem'Hadar?
No, but sensor range is less than two kilometers.
There might be a way we can increase it.
Minister Hanok, I think it would be best if you returned to the mess hall.
As you wish, Captain.
Mister Worf, what's our weapons status?
The cloak is ineffective inside this atmosphere. And the interference will jam our torpedo guidance systems.
What about phasers?
We'll have to target them manually.
Benjamin, we have an idea.

It's a little trick I learned during the occupation. We'd sometimes try to evade Cardassian ships by hiding in the Badlands. Sensor range was limited, so we learned to use an old active-scan system to navigate.
It works by echo-location... we send out a modulated tetrion pulse, and if it reflects off the hull of a ship, we can approximate its location.
Won't these pulses give away our position as well?
We'll have to alter course and speed after each one.
Good news, Minister.
Really?
I think I've found the problem.
I made the mistake of letting my brother Rom execute these contracts.
Your brother?

Yes. I'm ashamed to say it, but he's an idiot. You see, the Federation and the Karemma have very different laws governing commerce, and I think that Rom must've... gotten confused by all the legalisms.
Now, I'm more than willing to make up for any losses you might have suffered. In fact, I'll pay them back with interest.
You cheated me, Quark. And you don't even have the courage to admit it. If we survive this, I'll see to it that you never do business in the Gamma Quadrant again...
There's nothing within a thousand kilometers...
Ahead, one quarter impulse.
Try it again, Major...
There's something about four hundred kilometers below us. It could be the Karemma... I can't tell at this range.
Close to ten kilometers...
We're crossing into another thermal layer...
Holding position at ten kilometers.
Major...
From the size of it, I'd say it's the Karemma...
I'm picking up two more ships.
Shields at sixty percent.
Return fire.
. The Jem'Hadar are breaking off their attack...
Are they going after the Karemma?
I don't think they've spotted them...
Captain, impulse power is off line... we're losing altitude.
Try using thrusters to stabilize.
It's no use...
Hull pressure is at two million GSC and rising.
Sisko to Engine room. We need impulse power.
The primary ODN lines have overloaded, Captain... it's going to be a few minutes.
Chief, if you can spare someone to meet me in Jefferies Tube Four, I'll try to re-route power through the secondary couplings.
Muniz.
Yes, sir.
All right... let's recalibrate the ODN manifold.
I'll uncouple the plasma relay...
Sounds a little like a Yridian Symphony, doesn't it?
I don't know, I've never heard one.
Kind of nice, don't you think?
Hull pressure is at nine million GSC and still rising...
If we keep losing altitude at this rate, the hull will collapse in less than six minutes.
Sir, the phaser couplings overloaded during the attack. It will take at least two hours to repair them.
The Jem'Hadar aren't going to let us tractor the Karemma out of here without a fight.
Right now I'd say we're the ones who need to be tractored out of here.
One thing at a time, Major.
Sisko to O'Brien.
O'Brien, here.
How many atmospheric probes do we have on board?
Two.
Could they be rigged with warheads from the quantum torpedoes?
We'd have to pull out the imaging system to make room inside the casings, but I don't see why not.
How long?
Twenty minutes.
You've got ten.
You okay... ?
I'm all right...
The Captain's gotten us out of tougher spots than this.... last year, when the Romulans tried to invade the Founder's homeworld, we went up against a dozen Jem'Hadar ships
I know, Chief. You've told me the story.
Yeah? Well unless you want to hear it again, you'd better get down to the torpedo bay and start working on those probes.
I'm going.
Janklow, I'm going to need a dualitic inverter. There's one in the Cargo Bay.
Hull breach on Deck Two.
An emergency forcefield is in place, but it won't hold up long against this pressure...
How many people are down there?
Half a dozen in Sickbay... Dax and Muniz in Jefferies Tube Four.
We've got to get them out of there.
If we don't seal off that deck now, we'll lose the entire ship...
Sisko to Bashir.
Go ahead.
The emergency forcefield won't hold much longer. You've got to evacuate that deck so we can seal it off.
Aye, sir. Let's get everyone past that bulkhead...
Dax, are you finished?
Not quite.
Get out of there as soon as you're done. In about thirty seconds I'm going to have to seal that deck.
Understood.
We've got to get the engines back on-line. Just keep working and don't think about anything else.
Bashir to Bridge, I'm sealing the bulkhead.
Dax!
Hurry.
Jadzia!
The forcefield is down.
Doctor, close that bulkhead.
They're still in there.
Now, Doctor. That's an order.
Dax!
Bridge.
She did it.
Helm, take us to a higher altitude.
O'Brien to Bridge. One of the atmospheric probes is armed and standing by. We'll have the second one ready in a few minutes.
Very good, Chief.
All right, Major. Now that we've got something to defend ourselves with, let's start looking for the Karemma.
We're gaining altitude...
How can you tell?
I've got the lobes...
You've got them, too. It's a Ferengi expression. Usually, when we say someone has "the lobes," we mean they have a keen business sense. That's you.
I'll admit it. You fooled me. I thought you were just another easy mark. But you saw right through my little scam, and taught me a thing or two about doing business in the Gamma Quadrant.
I guess I've gotten lazy. I'm used to dealing with the Federation. You think I was cheating you, you have no idea what I was doing to them. They still haven't caught on.
And if someone like me can put one over on them, think of what someone like you could do.
Someone with my... lobes?
Exactly. And I'm just the man to help you do it. we could become rich, rich beyond our dreams.
You... are despicable.
I hate the Gamma Quadrant...
Sir, I have something. It's a Jem'Hadar ship.
Just one?
They must've split up to search for the Karemma.
It's about seventy kilometers above us, on a roughly perpendicular course.
Helm, come about to course zero- seven-five mark four. Let's fall in behind them.
Aye, sir.
Do you think they've detected us?
I don't know. Let's make it a little harder on them... shut down every non-essential system. It'll minimize our power signature...
All stop.
Program the probe to home in on the first metallic signature it finds.
If it doesn't locate anything within fifty kilometers, the probe might turn back and home in on the Defiant.
What if they've changed course, moved out of range?
Something tells me they're closer than you think...
The probe is ready, sir.
Fire.
O'Brien to Bridge...
Try the com-panel.
Engine Room to Bridge.
Bridge, please respond.
Save your breath, Muniz. I don't think there's anyone left alive up there.
Are you all right, major?
I think so...
Computer, lights. Bridge to Engine Room.
Boyce and Peterson are dead, sir...
Captain... try not to move... you took a bad blow... Get me a medkit.
Bridge systems are completely off- line. We're not getting power to these consoles.
There, the bleeding's stopped.
He's got a concussion... sub- cranial bleeding. We need a medic.
The com-system's down... I'll go below and try to find one.
I'm afraid if he loses consciousness, he could slip into a coma. But I don't think I can risk using a stimulant on him.
You have to keep him awake. Talk to him. Give him something to focus on.
Right.
I will attempt to get to the Engine Room and take control of the ship from there.
Good luck.
Captain...
Everything's going to be all right... but you have to try to stay awake for me...
I'm just going to talk, okay? I want you to listen. It's very important that you listen because... because there's going to be a test later.
How do you feel?
Terrible...
That's not surprising considering that you took in a few lungfuls of Fluorine.
Next time remind me to hold my breath... I take it we're stuck in here...
I thought about trying to crawl up the turbolift shaft, but it's flooded with gas.
I think I've had enough Fluorine for one day. Maybe we should just stay put and wait for someone to come get us.
They probably don't even know we're in here. Our com-signals can't cut through the interference.
Is there anything else I should know?
We only have a few hours of breathable air...
Thanks, anyway. For trying to rescuing me.
Lot of good it did you....
I mean it.
It's funny... if you'd have done something like this a year ago, I would've thought you were trying to be a hero.
And now?
Now that I know you better... I realize it was just a stupid thing to do.
You're welcome...
You're taking this too personally. Okay, I cheated you. I cheat everyone. It's business. You see what you can get away with, and you've got to figure the other guy's doing the same to you.
That's not the way the Karemma conduct business.
Oh, come on. You can't tell me you've never padded an inventory, or pawned off a load of substandard merchandise.
No, I haven't. The Karemma believe that merchandise has a set value, determined by the raw materials and labor involved in creating it.
Factor in transportation costs and a reasonable profit margin, and you arrive at a fair price.
You make it sound so... antiseptic. Where's the bargaining, where's the scheming... where's the greed?
Greed leads to misjudgment, which can result in the loss of profit.
If there's no risk, there's no thrill. It's just... ...barter. If you want to win big, you have to be willing to play the odds, it's like.... gambling.
Gambling is the last recourse of the desperate. Only a fool would risk losing what he has to chance.
Commander, am I glad to see you.
The captain is injured. All bridge functions are off-line.
We've been trying to route command functions to these consoles.
I will take command from here.
Who configured these helm controls?
I did, sir.
They are not laid out properly.
I realize they're not the same as on the bridge, but I had to make some changes because --
I need to be able to ascertain our status at a glance. Reconfigure these controls to their standard layout.
Aye, sir.
Mister Stevens, you will operate the echo-location system we've been using to track the Jem'Hadar.
I'll do my best.
I expect nothing less.
Let's get to work...

-- so I was thinking if we went to a four shift rotation, it would give people more flexibility with their time. There is a little bit of a downside because it means that every shift is going to have to -- what am I talking about?
I'm supposed to be keeping you awake, not boring you to tears. I'm sorry. I don't know why this is so hard. All I have to do is talk to you. I mean, what do we usually talk about?
Work...
You're right. That is what we usually talk about. Even when we're not working.
I get the feeling it's not that way with you and Dax, or you and Chief O'Brien.
Then again... you're not a revered figure in their religions.
I know you don't like it when I talk about you as the Emissary. But that is how I think of you. And maybe that's why it's sometimes hard for me to... relax around you.
Nerys... ?
Yes, sir?
Tell me a story...
All right. Do you know the one about the three brothers who went to Jo'kala?
No...

They were kava farmers, and one day they went out into their field and found the biggest kava root they'd ever seen, big as a house. "This will make us rich," said the oldest. And they decided to dig it up and sell it in the city.
Sir, I have something.
They're too small to be ships...
They're closing fast...
Torpedoes.
Hard to port!
I'm modulating the deflectors... it might confuse their guidance systems.
The second one's still closing... range, one hundred meters... seventy-five... fifty...
I suggest we leave this room immediately.
And go where? If that thing explodes, the entire ship will be destroyed. Maybe we should try to defuse it.
We should wait for help.
What if no one can get to us?
I don't like the sound of that. It's up to us...
There should be an emergency tool kit around here somewhere.
The arming mechanism must be somewhere in here. We have to remove this casing...
How?
There's no lock that can't be opened...
It looks like the torpedo hit somewhere in here.
Problem is, we're cut off from that part of the ship.
Mister Stevens, recalibrate the Structural Integrity Field to minimize the strain caused by the torpedo.
The field generators are already at their limit compensating for the hull breach on Deck Two.
I am aware of the situation, Mister Stevens. If you cannot carry out my orders, I will find someone who can.
That won't be necessary, sir.
Could I have a word with you, sir?
Of course.

With all due respect, I think you're riding these men a bit too hard. You have to understand, they're out of their element. They're not bridge officers, they didn't go to Starfleet Academy. They're Engineers. They're used to being told to repair something, and figuring out how to do it on their own.
What are you suggesting?
Just give them a little slack, ease up on the reins. Let them do what they're good at... and give them a little encouragement now and then.
I will take it under consideration.
I'm so cold...
These walls aren't that well insulated... it's going to get even colder... Better?
What?
Just remembering something.
Tell me.

When I first came to the station, I used to fantasize that you and I would go off on a runabout together on some mission. Something would go wrong with the ship... and we'd end up drifting around for a few days until they sent someone to rescue us.
If you don't mind my saying, Julian, that's a very strange fantasy.
I guess it seemed like the only way we'd ever get a chance to spend time alone together. You were always avoiding me.
It's just... you came on so strong. You didn't give me a chance to get to know you.
You're right, I didn't...
Don't worry, Jadzia. It's been a while since I had that particular fantasy.
How long a while... exactly?
I don't know. Couple of years, maybe.
Oh...
You're disappointed.
Julian.
That's it. You enjoyed being chased, and now you miss it.
That is preposterous. And if you start chasing after me again --
Now that I know you liked it, I don't need to, do I?
I require your assistance.
I need a weapon...
We still have one atmospheric probe.
If my plan is to work, the probe will not be available to use as a weapon. I need something else.
Phasers are out of the question, the emitters are completely fused.
But the phaser generator is working fine...
The Deflector Array.
With a few modifications, we could use it as a phaser emitter.
It may not be what you had in mind, sir...
And there is one problem... It'll overload after the first shot.
I only need one shot.
How long will it take to make the modifications?
Twenty minutes?
Ten if we can bypass the safeties.
Go.

... but then the brothers started to argue about how to divide the money they got for the kava root. The oldest said that since it was his idea to bring it to the city, he should get more. The youngest objected, saying he was the one who'd tended the field where...
This can't happen... you can't die... You're the Emissary... there's still so much you have to do...
I don't know if this is the right thing to do or not... but I'm going to give you a stimulant...
Captain... I know that my beliefs can make you feel uncomfortable around me. And that maybe they're the reason you keep me at arm's length sometimes.
But right now, I don't care about that. And that's why I hope you don't mind if I pray for a little while. I don't know what else to do. I'm losing you. And I can't let that happen.
Jia'kaja, tre'nu'tol'a rem... La'por i'lanu kos... I'nar tan'a'tali nor...
Everything's ready to go, sir.
We can target the deflector from here.
Good work.
Take your posts.
Mister O'Brien...
There's nothing within scanning range...
The Jem'Hadar are out there, Mister O'Brien... you can be certain of that...
Gently...
Okay... now what... ?
One of these diodes connects the warhead to the power source... the other is the firing mechanism.
How do you know that?
I saw a design schematic once.
Where?
At the Ministry of Trade on Karemma. We sell these torpedoes to the Jem'Hadar.
You're kidding.
No...
I thought you said you'd never sold substandard merchandise... It was supposed to explode on impact, wasn't it?
Maybe I should offer them a refund...
We'd better do something about this torpedo of yours...
We have to remove the firing diode... but I don't know which one it is...
And if we pick the wrong one... we die...
This isn't funny... we just have to pick the right one... it's fifty-fifty... better odds than you get at the dabo table...
dabo?
It's a game... if we get out of this, I'll teach it to you. Choose one.
How?
It's a gamble. Go with your instinct.
You're thinking too much. You just have to reach in and grab one.
Looks like we have a winner.
That was... exciting.
Feels good, doesn't it?
Yes...
That's how it works. The bigger the risk, the bigger the win. You know... there's another risk you could take... staying in business with me.
You never give up, do you?
No. I tried to cheat you, and I lost. That doesn't mean I'm going to give up the game... Come on, Hanok. What do you say... do you want to keep playing?
Let's talk about these Bolian currency fluctuations...
Jia'kaja, tre'nu'tol'a rem... La'por i'lanu kos... I'nar tan'a'tali nor...
Major... ?
Yes, captain?
What... happened... ?
The Jem'Hadar hit us pretty bad... Worf went down to the Engine Room to --
No, no...
What happened to the three brothers?
They gave the money away, and went back to their farm where they belonged.
Is good... Can you tell me another story... ?
I'd love to, sir...
Sir, I've got something.
It's the Jem'Hadar... they've locked onto the tetrion pulse...
Stand by, Mister Stevens...
Now.
What do you say we find the Karemma and get out of here?
Defiant Log, Supplemental.
Damage control teams are repairing the ship's systems and medics are tending to injured crewmembers.
We have located the Karemma ship deep in the atmosphere and are moving to assist. It appears that it will have to be abandoned...
... and its crew brought back to Deep Space Nine until transportation can be arranged to the Karemma Homeworld.
Oh! Pass five, too bad.
You lose half your stake. You can either quit now, or try to double it.
My advice is to take what latinum you have left and walk away.
Just because you lose a bet, that doesn't mean you give up the game.
Exactly.
May I suggest placing your next wager on double down.
Put it all on triple over.
I think you're making a big mistake.
Triple over. Nothing personal, Quark.
Of course not...
You're really catching on...
... seventeen brothers and sisters... ? That's quite a family.
Excuse me, Morn.
It's your turn.
For what?
Darts.
Oh, right. Sorry, Morn. Nice talking to you.
Thanks for rescuing me.
Now we're even.
Excuse me, sir.
Here's the repair schedule we drew up for the Defiant.
With your approval, we thought we'd start by tearing out the secondary ODN lines. They're shot, and it'll be easier to get to the manifolds that way. After that we figured we'd --
Proceed at your discretion, Mister Stevens.
Thank you, sir...
How long will the repairs take?
Sixteen hours.
You can do it in twelve.
Sure, twelve. No problem.
You have to give them a lot of slack, but you can't take your hands off the reins...
-- the Karemma transport will be here by eighteen hundred tomorrow, and the Defiant should be ready to escort them back to the Gamma Quadrant.
Good.
Major, it occurred to me that we should consider going to a four shift rotation. I think the crew might appreciate having more flexibility in their schedules.
I'll look in to it first thing in the morning.
What are you doing for the next few hours?
I'm going off duty, I thought I'd just relax.
You want to go to a ball game?
I'd love to, sir.
Meet me in Holosuite Three in half an hour.
See you then.
Nerys...
You'll need this...
You get the hot dogs from Quark...
Hot dogs?
He'll know...
It's a trick.
Of course it's a trick. But do you know how she did it?
She probably had the egg beamed directly into her mouth from one of the transporters.
Actually, one of my previous hosts used to dabble in sleight of hand.
Tobin, by any chance?
That's right.
He sounds like the type. Painfully shy, introverted, a certain lack of confidence... just the kind of person who would begin looking for ways to dazzle people with his "magical" abilities.
(still thinking about the trick) She swallowed the egg before she came into the bar. Then she regurgitated it on cue. Quite disgusting, actually.
Wrong again.
Sisko to Dax. I'd like to see you in my office, commander.
On my way, Benjamin. Don't worry, Quark. I'm sure you'll figure it out eventually.
Hmm... no wonder you can't figure it out.
What?
Your head's full of latinum.
Ladies and gentlemen: The Amazing Jadzia Dax!
Have a seat.
A Trill science team is on its way to the station. They're coming to conduct field tests on an experimental technique for creating artificial wormholes.
Sounds interesting.
It's an important project and I've agreed to let them use the Defiant for their experiments. But I thought you should know that the leader of the Trill science team... is Doctor Lenara Kahn.
Kahn? Lenara... Kahn?
That's right. You have about three months worth of leave accumulated. Why don't you take some of it? We can get along without you for a while.
Am I that dispensable around here?
We won't even notice you're gone.
No. I'll stay. I can handle it.
You sure?
I'm sure. I've never let my past lives interfere with my job and I'm not going to start now. I'll be fine.
Okay.
But thanks for giving me the option.
Any time... old man.
They... just finished docking.
Something wrong?
No.
I'm Doctor Hanor Pren of the Trill science ministry.
I'm Major Kira Nerys, and I'd like to welcome you to Deep Space Nine. This is our strategic operations officer, Commander Worf, and of course our science officer, Commander Dax.
Allow me to introduce our team leader Doctor Lenara Kahn and her brother Doctor Bejal Otner. (introducing them to the Trill) Major Kira, Commander Worf, and Commander Dax.
It's been a long time.
Yes, it has.
If you will come with me, I'll show you to your quarters.
You know that woman?
Oh, I know her. She used to be my wife.
So let me get this straight. Dax's first host was named Lela. Right?
I think so.
Lela Dax, that's right...
Then Lela dies and the Dax symbiont goes to a man named... Tobin. And after Tobin dies, then it's on to Emony... then... ... Torias.... Audrid...
No, no. Audrid, then Torias.
Sorry. Audrid, Torias, Joran, Curzon... and then finally Jadzia. And this Doctor Lenara Kahn person was once married to... ?
Torias. But of course she wasn't Lenara in those days.
I knew it couldn't be that simple.
The Kahn symbiont that's now joined to Lenara, used to be joined to a woman named Nilani. It was Nilani who married Torias Dax.
But Torias was killed in a shuttle accident...
And so Nilani became a widow. Years later, when she died, the Kahn symbiont was joined to Lenara.
And now... Nilani is Lenara, and Torias is Jadzia. So that makes Lenara Jadzia's ex-wife.
It's a little more complicated than that, Quark.
I'm sure it is. But to be honest, I'm sorry I brought the whole thing up. It's giving me a headache.
Must be all that latinum rattling around in there.
I was right. You really should have that looked at.
Get back to work.
If you'll excuse me...
Dax teach you that?
Next time I want to pull a rabbit out of his ear.
One thing I don't understand is why Dax and Lenara can't just... pick up where they left off. I mean, if they're still in love with each other --
Ah, but there's the rub. Even if they do harbor feelings for each other, it's strictly against the rules of Trill society for them to acknowledge it in any way.
The "rules?"
It's more of a... taboo, really. Having a relationship with a lover from a past life is called, "reassociation," and the Trill feel very strongly that it's... unnatural.
Unnatural? How can it be unnatural for a married couple to resume their marriage?

The whole point of joining is to allow the symbiont to accumulate experiences over the span of many lifetimes. But in order to move on from host to host, the symbiont has to let go of the past... let go of parents, children, siblings, even spouses.

I don't understand how two people who've fallen in love, and made a life together, can be forced to just... walk away from each other because of some... taboo. There must be some Trill that "reassociate" with people from their past.
I asked Dax the same question. And it seems there have been a few cases...
And what happened?
They were exiled from the Trill homeworld.
That would mean their symbionts would never be joined to new hosts.

Exactly. When the hosts die, the symbionts would die with them. So you see, however Dax may feel about Lenara, she's not going to risk that. To a joined Trill, nothing is more important than protecting the life of the symbiont. Nothing.
Come in.
I had a feeling you weren't going to be ready. I don't think Curzon was ever on time in his life. He was even late for his hundredth birthday party as I recall.
You're never going to let me forget that are you?
Do you know how long I planned that party?
Three months. I know.
It's still not too late to back out of this reception, you know.
You know me. I hate to miss a party.
I'm serious.
I know. And I appreciate what you're trying to do... but I'm going to be working with Lenara for the next week, so I better get used to being around her.
Stop worrying about me, Benjamin. I'll be fine.
... so in the spirit of friendship, we welcome you to Deep Space Nine and wish you success in creating the galaxy's first artificial wormhole.
Yes.
You must be very excited. To... be a part of a potentially history-making project.
I am... looking forward to it.
I think Mister Worf is less than enthusiastic about commanding a research mission. It's not exactly what every Klingon dreams about.
What do Klingons dream about, Worf?
Things that would send cold chills down your spine and wake you in the middle of the night. Believe me... it is better that you do not know.
I can never tell when he's joking.
Maybe it is "better that we do not know."
I thought you liked parties, Odo.
I enjoy parties that are given for my friends. But these diplomatic receptions... welcoming receptions... good-bye receptions... it all seems...
Unnecessary?
Exactly. I've never understood the humanoid obsession with bringing together groups of people and forcing them to interact socially.
Not all humanoids enjoy these functions.
Hmm. I think I may finally be starting to understand Mister Worf...
Well... this looks wonderful.
Mmmm-hmm.
I take it most of this is Bajoran.
Hasperat... moba fruit... veklava...
Of course, I'm not in the least bit hungry.
Me neither.
But I suppose we should load our plates anyway since the whole room is watching us.
Quite an audience.
Seems a shame to disappoint them. We should probably do something.
We could get into a screaming match... start throwing things at each other...
Not bad. Or I suppose we could throw ourselves at each other... profess our undying love and our complete disregard for Trill society.
Doctor Pren would probably have a heart attack.
Forget about him, my brother's head would explode. He's been a nervous wreck ever since we arrived.
I know the feeling.
Well, I'll tell you what I told him: we're both mature adults and we can handle this.
I agree completely. It's going to be fine.
They're watching again.
I know. I guess we better get used to it.
Thank you, Commander Dax. I appreciate your insightful commentary on Bajoran cuisine.
It was my pleasure, Doctor Kahn.
Well... that seemed to go well.
I never doubted it.

After we launch our target drone, the Defiant will have to generate a subspace tensor matrix in the twenty-five to thirty thousand Cochrane range. Then the drone will send out a magneton pulse which should react with the matrix and create an opening in the space- time continuum.
How long will we have to keep generating the matrix?
Two minutes, maybe less. Once the wormhole forms, we can shut down the tensor matrix.
We'll need to reroute the pre- ignition plasma from the impulse deck down to the auxiliary intake to get that much power... But I think we can do it.
Excellent.
We'll also need to download our parameters for the matrix into one of your computers.
We'd better use the main computer. I don't think the engineering computer can handle it.
I agree.
If you'll come with me, we can go up to the bridge and begin downloading the data.
All right.
Everything looks good here. Dax?
The backup navigation program is still showing some calibration drift. I think some data may have been lost in the startup routine.

Well, that explains the seven percent falloff in AFR ratios I keep seeing. There must be a problem in the diagnostic sub-routines. I have a recalibration unit back in my quarters that might solve the problem.
I'll have someone bring it here.
No, no. I need a break anyway.
Now I'm getting a dropoff in the triple-R output. We might have a bigger problem than the diagnostic subroutines.
Don't panic yet. It could just be a transtater failure. Happens all the time.
I wasn't panicking.
It's just an expression. (looks at her in surprise) Sorry.
No, I'm sorry. Forget it.
It's just that... you always used to -- I mean Torias always used to tell Nilani that she was panicking about things... making a big fuss over nothing.
Well... Torias could be insensitive at times... But... you have to admit, Nilani did do her share of overreacting.
That's because you were a pilot and it made me nervous -- made her nervous... Torias being a pilot made Nilani nervous.
I've never had quite this much trouble sorting out my feelings from those of a past host.
I know what you mean.
Probably another reason why we're not supposed to spend much time together... we'd just get lost in the past.
Let's try running the transtater diagnostic again.
Okay.
Nilani wasn't panicking the day before Torias died.
No?

No. Torias should've listened to her. The shuttle wasn't ready for a full impulse test... but Torias had to do it anyway... and he was wrong. And whatever part of me is still Torias... is very sorry... and wishes he'd listened to you.
Well... we still have a lot of work to do.
Right.
Would you be interested in dinner? I mean I'm having dinner with some friends and I thought... maybe you'd like to... join us?
I wouldn't want to intrude on your friends...
It's actually... not that big a group... it's really just me and... Julian.
Doctor Bashir? Sure. That sounds great.
Great.
Okay. Dinner. Tonight.
At Quark's.
Great.
Tonight? I can't, I have plans.
Cancel them. I mean, if you can cancel them it would be... nice.
It'll be nice because... ?
Because... I've invited Lenara out to dinner and...
And it would be less awkward if you had a... chaperone.
Exactly. Will you do it?
Something tells me I should say no... but I won't. What time?
Twenty-two hundred at Quark's. Thanks. I owe you one.
... No, it didn't have a red awning. It had a... big ratana tree or something out front.
You don't mean the "Barros Inn?"
Yes! That's it.
Curzon got thrown out of the Barros Inn? That's one of the wildest bars in the Rigel system. What did he do?
Well, he sort of set fire to it...
Sort of?
All right, he did set fire to it. But it wasn't deliberate. It was part of a bet. But that's another story.
Curzon was certainly... different from most joined Trills.
He liked to do things his own way. He used to say that there was an exception to every rule... and he usually went out of his way to find it.
In a way I'm glad I never met him. We probably wouldn't have liked each other very much.
Oh, he wasn't that bad. I tend to exaggerate his rebellious qualities. But you may have a point... Curzon never did have much use for scientists.
Well, that's interesting considering what you do now.
Curzon would be horrified to know that I'm a scientist. The very idea of doing research made him ill.
Torias was not much different. I can remember talking to him about my wanting to study theoretical quantum physics and his eyes glazed over.
The irony is that you and I have more in common than Torias and Nilani ever did.
That's right...
Infirmary to Doctor Bashir.
Bashir here, go ahead.
I'm sorry to disturb you, Doctor. But Ensign Tyler's broken his leg and I think you should --
I'm on my way. Sorry. But duty calls.
It's all right. Thanks for coming.
Nice to see you again.
Now that is a good friend. He sat here and listened to us trade stories about our former hosts all night and never once complained.
I think he really enjoyed himself.
Okay, maybe not. But I'll make it up to him.
Those are Klingon aren't they?
How'd you know?
Curzon?
They were a gift from a Klingon scientist. He wanted to give me one of those knives they're always carrying, but I refused.
They're beautiful.
Keep them. Really. I'm... not very Klingon.
Thank you.
Well?
They suit you. It's good to see you again, Dax. That sounds strange, doesn't it?
I mean, I'm looking at a different face, hearing a different voice... but somehow, it's still you.
I know. Every time I start to think of you as just Lenara, you'll smile or laugh... and suddenly... it's you.
I'm really glad you're here.
Me too.
Defiant Log: Stardate 49195.5. We have arrived at the coordinates to begin preliminary tests for the artificial wormhole project.
The target drone is in position, commander.
Full scan.
No ships within sensor range.
Bridge to Engine room. Are you ready, Mister Eddington?
We're ready, Commander.
Doctor Kahn, you may proceed.
Energize the focal array and stand by to initiate the subspace tensor matrix.
This AQF sequencer is always giving me problems.
Maybe it doesn't like you.
How could it not like me? I'm adorable.
That is a matter of opinion.
I'll have you know that the word adorable is used three times in my Starfleet personnel file.
The plasma coil interlocks are in place... deflector grid is charged and standing by...
They're very friendly today.
Mmm.
They had dinner last night... alone.
What're you trying to say?
I shouldn't have to say anything.
Then don't.
We're ready to generate the tensor matrix.
The drone is standing by.
Initialize the focal array.
Activate the drone.
The drone is sending out the magneton pulse... It's reached the matrix...
I'm picking up a subspace distortion...
The distortion is becoming coherent... it's working!
The magneton pulse is causing a feedback loop... it'll destroy the drone in a few seconds.
A few seconds is all we need...
There it is.
The drone's been destroyed. But you did it!
Congratulations, Doctor.
Thank you. That was only the first step. But what a step!
I'm so proud of you.
All the telemetry checks out... the wormhole was open for twenty- three point four seconds, and during that time it was completely coherent.
You couldn't ask for a better beginning. But it all comes down to the next test. We have to be able to send an object through the wormhole to prove that it's stable enough for space travel.
That reminds me... Dax thinks we should use a Class Four probe to make the actual run. She says the Class Four shielding will give us a better idea of how the wormhole will affect a real ship.
Oh... I didn't know you talked to Dax since we got back.
I saw her last night.
Where?
She stopped by my quarters...
And how long did she stay?
Is there something you want to ask me?
I don't want to ask you anything... but I'm starting to wonder if I should.
I don't believe this.
Believe it. People are starting to notice.
People?
Doctor Pren saw you holding hands at dinner the other night. I thought he was overreacting, but then I saw the way the two of you were acting on the Defiant...
Lenara... Lenara!
I'm sorry... I'm sorry.
Look... I'm your brother. You tell me nothing's going on... then nothing's going on. I just want to hear you say it.
There is nothing going on. All right?
All right.
Come in.
What's wrong?
I just had an unpleasant conversation with my brother. He thinks there's something going on between us.
Oh. What'd you tell him?
I told him that was ridiculous... that you and I are just friends and of course there's nothing going on.
Well, then that should settle it.
Maybe we shouldn't spend time together... it'll just give people the wrong idea.
Or give them the right idea.
Maybe we shouldn't have this conversation.
Would that do any good... would it change how either of us feels?
No... but it would be easier.
You've never been one for the easy way out.
That's true. But in this case, I'm not the only one involved. I don't want to do anything that would hurt you. I did that once before... I climbed into a shuttlecraft and made you a widow.
I knew you were a pilot when I married you. I knew the risks. I went in with my eyes wide open.
And what about now... are your eyes open... do you know what the risks are?
I thought I'd gotten over you... it's been so long... so much has happened. But now I know I haven't...
I've missed you so much.
I'd better go.
Yeah.
I don't know what to do, Benjamin.
What do you want to do?
Throw myself at her... profess my undying love and my complete disregard for Trill society. A joke Lenara made at the reception. Doesn't sound so funny anymore, does it?
Not really.
You don't think I should pursue this.
No.
Okay. Why?
Because I remember what Curzon used to say about "reassociation." That it didn't matter whether he agreed with the taboo or not.
Because the price for violating it was too high. Exile.
I know what Curzon used to say, Benjamin. But I'm not Curzon.
You're not Torias, either. You're Jadzia Dax and you have a responsibility as a joined Trill to --
I didn't come here for a lecture on my responsibilities.
What you came here for was to get advice from a friend. And that's what you're getting.
You're right. Sorry.
I know this is difficult for you. And I know how you feel about Lenara... but I want you to think about what'll happen if you pursue this.
If you're exiled from Trill... there'll be no further hosts for your symbiont. When Jadzia dies... Dax dies.

It goes against everything you were taught during initiate training. You've told me again and again that each host is only a link in a chain... and that no matter what happens, the life of the symbiont must go on.
I know that... and I believe in it. But I also know that I love her, Benjamin.
I know you do. And if I were in your position... I'd probably be just as ready to throw everything away for the woman I love. But I'd want to be sure that I was ready to pay the price.
You're right. I have to be sure.
But if you are sure... if this is what you really want... I'll back you up... all the way.
I've lived seven lifetimes... and I've never had a friend quite like you.
Eddington to Bridge. We're ready to generate the tensor matrix.
Understood. Stand by. Commander Dax?
Subspace field stress is within normal parameters.
The probe's ready for launch.
The target drone is in position.
Bridge to Engine Room. Initialize the subspace matrix, Mister Eddington.
Acknowledged.
Activate the drone.
Wormhole neutrino readings... are stable.
Subspace field stress is up by fifteen percent... but still within safety margins.
Launch the probe.
Report.
No helm control... there's a hull breach on Deck Five... emergency forcefields are in place.
I'm reading a massive plasma leak in the Engine Room.
Bridge to Engine Room. Mister Eddington. Doctor Kahn can you hear me?
Have a damage control team meet me down there.
Stand back.
It's out of control. We can't put it out with those. We'll have to vent the entire compartment out into space.
scene: 50   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - UPPER LEVEL (OPTICAL)

quote: No. Lenara might still be alive.
scene: 50   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - UPPER LEVEL (OPTICAL)

quote: There's no way to get to her.
scene: 50   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - UPPER LEVEL (OPTICAL)

quote: How long will a level eight forcefield last in here?
scene: 50   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - UPPER LEVEL (OPTICAL)

quote: Not long with that plasma fire. Four, five seconds at the most.
scene: 50   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - UPPER LEVEL (OPTICAL)

quote: I think I can get to her.
scene: 50   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - UPPER LEVEL (OPTICAL)

quote: Dax, if we don't contain this thing now, it's going to set off the warp core.
scene: 50   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - UPPER LEVEL (OPTICAL)

quote: I know. Just give me ten seconds and then vent the compartment.
scene: 50   INT. DEFIANT - ENGINE ROOM - UPPER LEVEL (OPTICAL)

quote: Dax...
I thought I lost you...
So did I... I don't want to lose you... not again...
Not again... never again...
Come in.
How're you feeling?
Much better. She's almost fully recovered.
My brother the nurse.
I want to thank you... for what you did. Lenara... means a lot to me.
To both of us.
Yes. I'll leave you two alone.
Do they know what happened to the wormhole yet?
Our best guess at this point is that the tetrion field reacted to the probe's shielding and produced a massive graviton wave.
The important thing is that no one was killed and we brought the ship back in one piece.
The ship. How bad was the damage?
Chief O'Brien says he'll have it good as new in two weeks. Now stop torturing yourself. It wasn't your fault.
It was my project... my theories...
And you shouldn't forget that your project and your theories still produced the first artificially created wormhole in history. It's a huge achievement.
You're right. I am being a little self-indulgent aren't I?
Yes. You are.
Well. I guess I'll have a lot of work to do when I get back to Trill. Analyzing the telemetry from the probe alone will probably take months.
Probably.
Why not do the work here... with me.
With you. The two of us... together. You know what that would mean...
I know exactly what it would mean. But I think it's worth the price.
That's funny... Bejal just spent the last half hour telling me that it wouldn't be worth it. He thinks I should go back to Trill with him tomorrow and try to forget about you.
Well, at least he's consistent.
Don't be too hard on him. He's only trying to look out for his big sister.

Everyone's trying to... look out for us. Protect us from ourselves. But in the end, all that matters is how we feel... and what we do about it. Because either way, we're the ones who have to live with the consequences.
That's the tricky part though, isn't it? Living with the consequences.
When you're not around, it's like part of me is missing. I want to be with you more than anything... But I don't think I can do this...
I'm not like you, Dax... I don't have a little Curzon inside me telling me to be impulsive... to ignore the rules... give up everything I've worked for...
Can you really walk away from me... from us? After all this time we're back together. Don't throw that away.
I don't want to... Maybe I need more time... maybe if I go back to Trill for a while... think it over... I could always come back later...

I wish I could believe that. But ultimately, it comes down to this... if you feel about me the way I feel about you... you won't get on that transport tomorrow. And if you do leave... I think we both know you're never coming back.
Late at night. Both levels are completely deserted and the lights are low. There's an eerie quality to the play of light and shadows on the Promenade floor.
Nerys?
Vedek Bareil. Want to play?
Help me.
Please.
All right.
Who is it?
It's Prylar Bek.
No it's not.
It's you.
I thought you'd sleep until noon.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Shh. You're supposed to be relaxing.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Oh, I'm... very relaxed.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Good.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: And how are you feeling this morning?
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Miserable. I wish you could stay here longer.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: All right, I will. I'll stay a few more days.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: You know you can't do that.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Why not?
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Because in two days, you're going to be elected Kai.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Oh, that. You know there's no guarantee that I'm going to win.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Of course you're going to win. The people need you.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Are you going to vote for me?
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Is that why you spent the past three days here? To get my vote?
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Well, I know you don't agree with many of my views. So I thought a personal appearance might sway your opinion.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: I was going to vote for Vedek Tolena...
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: But I suppose I might be persuaded to change my mind.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Good. Because your vote is the only one that matters to me.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: I may not always agree with your interpretations of the prophecies, but I think you'll make a wonderful Kai. Besides, everyone knows you were Kai Opaka's personal choice to succeed her.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: I could never replace Opaka. Bajor wouldn't have survived the occupation without her.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Once you become Kai, we'll never have these times together.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Listen to me, Nerys... No matter how busy I become... I'll always have time for you.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: It won't be easy...
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: I didn't say it would be. But I'm not going to lose you, Nerys. I promise you that.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: I have to report for duty in less than an hour.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: My ship leaves even sooner.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: That doesn't leave us much time.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: The Prophets say that time is an illusion. That a minute can last an eternity if you let it.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: Do you really believe that?
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: I'm willing to give it a try.
scene: 14   INT. KIRA'S QUARTERS - CLOSE ON BAREIL

quote: (to the children; benevolently) I can't tell you how much it pleases me to see such beautiful, happy children... Remember now, honor the Prophets and they will always love you.
As I understand the Sacred Texts, the Prophets' love is unconditional. They ask nothing in return.
Thank you, Vedek Bareil, for reminding us how the Sacred Texts can be easily misinterpreted.
Nothing pleases me more than providing you with an opposing viewpoint, Vedek Winn.
Somehow you never fail to do that. I had no idea you were on the station. But I suppose I shouldn't be too surprised.
I would never even try to surprise you, Winn. I understand you've been keeping a very close eye on my activities these last few weeks.
The eyes of all of Bajor have been focused on you, Bareil. Why should I be any different? After all, the common wisdom is that you're destined to be the next Kai.
Was that a concession speech?
Hardly. The choosing is still two days away. The Prophets may yet surprise us all. (to Bareil, with a curt look to Kira) Remember that, Bareil. I would hate for you to start celebrating prematurely.
I'd never dream of it. Not with such distinguished opponents as yourself and Vedek Tolena still under consideration.
All I ask is that the people follow the will of the Prophets.
I'm sure they will.
What brings you to the station, Vedek Winn?
My child, if I thought the Prophets wanted you to know the purpose of my visit, I would've informed you of it in advance.
Now that I know that you're here, I'll be sure to inform Constable Odo to increase station security.
That won't be necessary. I feel quite safe here.
It wasn't your safety that concerned me.
Just what are you trying to infer, child?
I'm sure Major Kira meant no disrespect.
Oh, no. None at all. I just want to make sure we avoid the violence that occurred during your last visit.
My child, I know you still hold me responsible for the deplorable attempt on Vedek Bareil's life. I can only pray that someday you will be cured of that unfortunate misconception.
You can be sure that's one prayer that'll never be answered.
What a pity... for both of us.
(trying to extricate himself) Well, I'm afraid I have a transport to catch.
Of course you do. I'm glad we've had this chance to talk.
May the Prophets guide your path.
And watch your every step.
Excuse me...
Wait... I know you...
You must be mistaken.
No. I've seen you before. You... You're... Kubus. Kubus Oak. You worked for the Cardassians.
Move. Get out of my way.
What are you doing? Don't let him get away. He's a traitor. Stop him.
You're not going anywhere.
What's going on here...
See for yourself.
Secretary Kubus. Last I heard, you were living on Cardassia.
I decided it was time to come home.
Welcome back. You're under arrest.
The Prophets have spoken. All blessings on the new Kai.
Kai Bareil... Blessings on the Kai... May the Prophets guide you... Follow your pagh...
Kai Opaka?
Be at peace, my child. You must be strong... now more than ever.
Why did you leave us?
All is as the Prophets will it to be. As you will learn. Follow me.
Be careful, Bareil. The path she walks is a narrow one. See that you don't stumble.
Heed her words.
But I don't deserve to walk in your path.
You must. It is your destiny.
Prylar Bek?
Accept this gift from the Prophets.
You must not refuse their offering.
Take it, my child. Its venom will make you stronger.
There was quite a mob gathering out there. I had to call in extra security to disperse it.
I never doubted your ability to handle the situation, Odo. You always were good at your job.
I could say the same for you. Secretary Kubus. Special liaison between the Cardassian Occupation Forces and their pawns in the Bajoran government.
I served the only recognized government on Bajor during the Occupation.
Recognized... by the Cardassians.
If it wasn't for us, the situation on Bajor would've been ten times worse than it was.
Maybe. But I don't see how you could know that... seeing that you spent nearly all your time here on the station. I remember Gul Dukat telling me once that you were his favorite Bajoran.
Really? I never could stand that arrogant tyrant.
You hid your feelings well.
It kept me alive. Tell me about Bajor, Odo. On Cardassia one hears so many rumors.
What kind of rumors?
Oh, revolutions... famine... bloodshed...
Is that why you came back? To suffer along with your fellow Bajorans. I hope you won't be disappointed to learn that things are nowhere near that bad.
Believe me... starving would be better than living another year on Cardassia.
Didn't your Cardassian hosts treat you well?
They treated me extremely well. Anything I wanted was mine for the asking... and I hated every minute of it. Bajor is my home. I never should've left.
But you did. And you're going to have to live with that decision.
This is Major Kira, the highest- ranking Bajoran on the station.
Then I suppose you're the one I should be talking to.
Make it brief. I don't enjoy talking to collaborators.
I'm not asking you to like me. I'm simply requesting that I be allowed to return home.
Your request is denied.
I doubt you have the authority to make that decision.

But the decision's already been made. In the Ilvian Proclamation, all Bajorans who were members of the Cardassian Occupational Government were sentenced to exile. Your name was number four on the list. Personally, I think you all got off too easy.
I'd like to appeal that ruling.
There are no appeals. You'll be placed on the next transport headed out of Bajoran space.
Until then, I suggest you remain in my custody... for your own safety.
Major, I'm an old man. I don't have many years left. What's the harm in letting me live them out on Bajor?
When the Cardassians needed a new group of Bajorans to work in the mines, who approved the work orders?
The Bajoran Government.
Whose signature was on the authorization forms?
Mine.
You had to know those authorizations were death sentences. Did you ever once refuse to sign them?
No.
And that's why you can never be allowed to set foot on Bajor again. If you did, it would dishonor the memory of every person you sentenced to death.
Vedek Winn. What can I do for you?
Emissary, it has recently come to my attention that there are some on Bajor who believe my relationship with you is not all it should be.
Really?
Personally, I find such a perception, however inaccurate, to be most distressing.
I suppose the question we have to ask ourselves is whether or not that perception is inaccurate?
Don't tell me that you, yourself, Emissary, believe you and I are... how shall I put this...
Enemies?
At odds.

Well, let's see. How could I have come to such a conclusion? Maybe it has something to do with the fact that the last time you were on this station, you claimed I was a danger to Bajor. That I was here to destroy your people.
I'm afraid you, like some others, may have misinterpreted me. Though I agree that, taken out of context, my words might appear... inflammatory.
Perhaps you should clarify yourself.

What I was really saying... and what I have always maintained... is that you, Emissary, were sent here by the Prophets, to challenge our long-held beliefs. To enable Bajorans everywhere to come to a new, deeper understanding of our personal spirituality.

I see. I have to admit that interpretation never occurred to me. Let me make sure there are no further misunderstandings between us. Am I right in assuming that you no longer consider the Federation to be an enemy of Bajor?
Emissary, I admit that I had some concerns about Bajor's application for Federation membership. But now I see that the Federation's presence here is essential to our long-term security and growth.
Then you support the idea of Bajor joining the Federation?
If that is the will of the Prophets, I would never oppose it.
I'd be grateful if you'd tell that to the Bajoran people.

Nothing would make me happier than to please you, Emissary. (Winn brightens as if she's just had a great idea) Perhaps you and I could address the Vedek Assembly together. So that everyone can celebrate our new friendship.
An excellent idea. Maybe some time next week...
Why wait, Emissary? I'm sure the Assembly would grant us an immediate audience.
I'm sure they would. Unfortunately, if we were to appear in public together before the choosing, it might be misconstrued as an endorsement of your bid to become Kai.
I doubt that, Emissary. It's common knowledge that you support Vedek Bareil. Although I've been pleasently surprised that you haven't made any public statement to that effect. As of yet.
The election of the Kai is strictly an internal matter to Bajor. As a Federation officer, I would never interfere.
What an enlightened philosophy.

(not letting her off the hook) So then, it's agreed. I'll be seeing you sometime next week. I'm sure our appearing together in front of the Vedek Assembly will do wonders for Federation/Bajoran relations.
I look forward to it.
Vedek Winn... Security Chief Odo has requested that you stop by his office before leaving the station.
(nods in acknowledgement) Please inform him that I'll be there shortly.
Odo to Major Kira.
This is Kira.
Major... sorry to disturb you. But I thought you should know... Secretary Kubus is about to leave for Bajor.
How can that be?
Vedek Winn has granted him sanctuary.
I'll be right there.
Kira to Ops.
Go ahead.
Dax, has Winn's ship left the station?
Not yet, but I was about to clear them for departure.
Keep those docking clamps locked on. I don't want that ship going anywhere until I say so.
Understood.
Tell me what happened.

(eyes still on the computer) Kubus requested a private meeting with Vedek Winn. They talked for ten minutes. After which Winn asked for the use of my computer. She accessed some information from the library system.
And?
And then she called the Provisional Government and informed them she was granting Kubus sanctuary.
Do you know what she looked up?
I'm trying to find out right now.
Hmm.
That's Prylar Bek. Why would Winn be interested in another Bajoran collaborator?

I'm not sure. But Bek and Kubus did know each other. Bek was the liaison between the Cardassians and the Vedek Assembly at the same time Kubus was Secretary to the Occupational Government. They spent a lot of time together on the station.
Hold on a minute. See if Winn accessed any information on the Kendra Valley Massacre.
You're right, she did. Do you think Kubus told her something new about the Massacre?
What else is there to know?

Kai Opaka's son and forty-two other Bajoran freedom fighters were ambushed and killed because Bek gave the Cardassians the location of their encampment. He made a full confession in his suicide note. You were here then. You must've read it yourself.
Major Kira.
May I speak to you?
Of course.
I was told you were the one who stopped my ship from leaving.
That's right. I did. You're the last person I would expect to help a collaborator like Kubus. Unless, of course, he has something you need.
My needs are no concern of yours, child. Now I suggest that you allow my ship to depart immediately.

You're free to leave any time you want. Unfortunately, in light of public feelings about Kubus, I can't allow any ship with him aboard to leave the station until it's undergone a thorough security check to prevent sabotage.
And that includes a molecular scan for nanotechnology.
How long would such a scan take?
I'm no expert, but I'm sure it could take days... or even weeks.

Very well. It seems the Prophets have decided you will have a part in this after all. (laying her cards on the table) In exchange for sanctuary, Kubus has agreed to provide the name of the man who was responsible for the Massacre at Kendra Valley.
Prylar Bek was responsible for the massacre. Everyone knows that.
Bek was a pawn... an intermediary. He killed himself to prevent the discovery of the real traitor.
The real traitor?
Bek's superior... the person who ordered him to reveal the location of the rebel base to the Cardassians... the man who was truly responsible for the massacre... Vedek Bareil.
Do you really think I'm going to let you get away with this? No one's going to believe the word of a convicted traitor like Kubus.
I never said I believed him either. I'm only trying to protect the spiritual life of Bajor.
Don't flatter yourself. You're trying to grab power. Nothing more.
My child, do you want to risk the consequences of having a collaborator become the next Kai?
He's not a collaborator.

That's yet to be determined. But if he is chosen, and then turns out to be guilty... the ramifications for Bajor would be catastrophic. It would shatter faith in the authority of the Kai. And without a strong Kai, Bajor can't survive.
But you can't condemn Bareil without proof.
I don't intend to. I was planning to conduct a quiet investigation when I returned to Bajor. But I didn't know who to trust with such a delicate assignment. Until now.
You want me to do your dirty work for you.
All I care about is the truth. And I believe the Prophets have chosen you to help me find it.
I'll find the truth. Don't worry about that. But I want you to keep Kubus's accusations from becoming public until I've had a chance to prove Bareil's innocence.
You have my word. Let the Prophets be my witness. But if you discover proof of his guilt...
Whatever I find out, I'll share with you.
Then it's decided.
Oh, and child, one last thing. I know you're under a terrible strain, but if you're wise, you'll never speak to me with such disrespect again.
It was the day after the raid...
You mean the massacre.
(a slight reprimand to Kira) I think we all know what happened that terrible day.
I just want to make sure he gets his story straight.
Don't worry about that, Major. Do you think I could forget the deaths of forty-three Bajorans, one of whom was the Kai's son?
Were you aware at the time that Prylar Bek was a collaborator?

(dismissive of the idea) He wasn't a collaborator. He was only a messenger between the Cardassians and the Vedek Assembly. But I could see in the weeks prior to the massacre that something was bothering him. He was tense, nervous. He was in constant communication with someone in the Vedek Assembly.
Do you know who?
Not at the time... but the day after the... incident, Vedek Bareil came to visit him on the station.
You saw them together?
I saw Bareil enter Bek's quarters, which were in the same section as mine. He was in there for a couple of hours. At times I heard shouting through the bulkhead.
Did you hear what they were saying?
No. But I did see Bareil when he left the station.
He looked very upset. The next morning, Bek hung himself.
That's all the evidence you have?
Isn't that enough? Bek was obviously working with Bareil. When he realized the enormity of what he'd done, he must've wanted to confess. Bareil wouldn't allow it, so Bek took the only way out he had.
That's a fascinating story but it's all conjecture. There could be a dozen explanations for why Bareil came to see Bek.
And it's up to you to find out which of those explanations is true.
What exactly is it that you're asking me, Nerys?
I guess I'm asking whether or not you came to the station to see Bek that day.
I visited Bek, yes. But that hardly makes me a collaborator.
I know that. It's Vedek Winn who needs convincing.
Poor Winn. I'm afraid her desire to become Kai has clouded her judgement.
I wouldn't take her lightly, if I were you. She's determined to ruin you.
Nerys, I know you're concerned for me. And I appreciate it... more than you know. I wish you could be here with me right now.
So do I.
But believe me when I tell you, there's no reason to worry. I had nothing to do with the massacre. And Winn will never be able to prove otherwise.
All right. But I still need to know why you came to the station.
Because Bek was a deeply troubled man seeking spiritual guidance. His guilt from betraying the Kendra Valley base was overwhelming.
He called me for help and I came as soon as I could... I only wish I'd been able to do more for him.
What did he tell you about the massacre?
Nerys, you have to understand, he was a monk speaking in confidence to his Vedek. I can't betray that trust.
I understand. But is there anything else you think I should know? About Bek, or the massacre?
Nothing that will satisfy Winn.
Then I'll have to keep looking. But one way or another, I'm going to prove to Winn that you're innocent.
Thank you, Nerys. I don't know what I'd do without you.
I wouldn't worry about that... I'm not going anyplace.
Just as I thought. When the Cardassians left, they purged all records of communication between the station and Bajor.
Then we'll have to get the information from the other end.
I'll establish a computer link with the Bajoran Central Archives. That way I can access the files of the Vedek Assembly.
Are you all right?
I'm fine.
You don't look fine.
It's nothing.
If you say so.
I mean, he says he's not guilty. I know he's not guilty...
But you're afraid he's guilty.
I love him, Odo.
Really... Well... I...
What?
I was wondering when you were going to figure that out. You humanoids... when it comes to emotional attachments, you never see the obvious. I'm into the Vedek Assembly archives.
Can you retrieve the communications records between the station and the Assembly.
I'll need a time frame.
Try the week leading up to the Kendra Massacre.
That's odd...
What?
All the communications records between the Assembly members and Bek for that week have been sealed.
Sealed by who?
